title: Introduction to Python
content:
Welcome to Python Programming!

Python is one of the world's most popular programming languages. Created by Guido van Rossum in 1991, Python emphasizes readability and simplicity.

Why Learn Python?
• Easy to learn and read
• Versatile - used in web development, data science, AI, automation
• Huge community and libraries
• High demand in job market

Your First Program:
The traditional first program in any language is 'Hello, World!' - it simply displays text on screen.

In Python, we use the print() function to display output.

miniExercise.task: Write a program that prints your name

title: Variables - Storing Data
content:
Variables in Python

Variables are like labeled boxes that store data. You can put information in them and retrieve it later.

Key Points:
• Variables have a name and a value
• Python automatically figures out the data type
• Variable names should be descriptive
• Use lowercase with underscores (snake_case)

Creating Variables:
variable_name = value

Rules for Variable Names:
✓ Can contain letters, numbers, underscores
✓ Must start with letter or underscore
✓ Case-sensitive (age and Age are different)
✗ Cannot use Python keywords (if, for, while, etc.)
✗ No spaces or special characters

Why Use Variables?
• Store data for later use
• Make code flexible and reusable
• Give meaning to values

title: Numbers in Python
content:
Working with Numbers

Python has two main number types:

1. Integers (int)
• Whole numbers (positive, negative, or zero)
• Examples: 5, -3, 0, 1000
• No decimal point

2. Floating-Point (float)
• Numbers with decimal points
• Examples: 3.14, -0.5, 2.0
• Used for precise calculations

Basic Math Operations:
+ Addition: 5 + 3 = 8
- Subtraction: 10 - 4 = 6
* Multiplication: 6 * 7 = 42
/ Division: 15 / 3 = 5.0
// Floor Division: 17 // 5 = 3
% Modulus (remainder): 17 % 5 = 2
** Exponent: 2 ** 3 = 8

Order of Operations (PEMDAS):
Parentheses → Exponents → Multiplication/Division → Addition/Subtraction

Example: 2 + 3 * 4 = 14 (not 20!)
examples:

sum = x + y
print(sum)  # 13

price = 19.99
quantity = 3
